raw_text:
Blair's hope for Blunkett return
 
 The events leading to David Blunkett's resignation must not "swept under the carpet", the Tories have warned.
 
 On Wednesday Tony Blair said he hoped the former home secretary would serve again in government in the future. Mr Blunkett quit in December after a probe linked him to the visa application of his ex-lover's nanny. Mr Blair said he left "without a stain on his character" but Tory Dominic Grieve branded the way Mr Blunkett's office operated as "scandalous". Mr Blair told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I know David very well and I believe him to be a man of real integrity and real ability and I was very sad for him as to what happened."
 
 He said Mr Blunkett still had an immense amount to offer the country but he was not making any "guarantees or definitive statements" about future jobs. But shadow attorney general Mr Grieve said: "While I don't rule out the possibility that Mr Blunkett may return as a minister, I don't think it's something that can simply be brushed under the carpet." Senior Labour backbencher Martin O'Neill, who chairs the Commons trade committee, said he believed the prime minister would want one of his "praetorian guard" - a reference to the elite body guard of Roman emperors - back alongside him. But colleague Ian Gibson, who chairs the science and technology committee, said there was a "question mark" as to whether Mr Blunkett could serve at cabinet level again.
llama3.2:1b: David Blair hopes former Home Secretary David Blunkett will return to government in the future after his resignation in December amid a scandal surrounding visa applications linked to his ex-lover's nanny.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair hopes David Blunkett will return to government in the future, but Tory Dominic Grieve warns that the scandal surrounding Blunkett's resignation cannot be swept under the carpet.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair expressed hope for David Blunkett's return to government but acknowledged his resignation due to a visa scandal. Dominic Grieve criticized Blunkett's office operation.  Blair believes Blunkett has integrity and ability, but offered no guarantees. Mr. Grieve believes Blunkett may return as a minister, while Martin O'Neill thinks the prime minister would have him close. Ian Gibson questioned his cabinet level potential.
qwen2.5:0.5b: David Blair wants former Home Secretary David Blunt to stay in government, but Tory Party leader Lord Grieve says it is "swept under the carpet". Tony Blair told Today he believed Blunt was a man of integrity and "not guilty until proven guilty", though Lord Grieve said ministers were not making promises or guarantees about future jobs. Senior Labour backbencher Martin O'Neill believes prime minister Theresa May would want a praetorian guard in Blunt's place, while Ian Gibson doubts whether he could serve at cabinet level again.
qwen2.5:1.5b: David Blunkett resigned after an investigation found he improperly handled a nanny's visa application for his ex-partner. Tony Blair hopes Blunkett returns to cabinet but warns of potential scandals; Conservative Dominic Grieve doubts Blunkett can return due to past misconduct and the possibility of future investigations.
qwen2.5:3b: The Tories warn against ignoring David Blunkett's resignation probe. Tony Blair expressed hope for Blunkett’s future in government despite criticisms from Dominic Grieve. Labour figures support his return, though some doubt if he can be a cabinet minister again.

Blair's hope for Blunkett return

The events leading to David Blunkett's resignation must not have been swept under the carpet by the Tories' warning. Tony Blair said he hoped the former home secretary would serve again in government in the future, leaving Mr Blunkett at a disadvantage in the race.

He quit December after a probe linked him to the visa application of his ex-lover's nanny, marking a departure from his formal duties as a home secretary. Mr Blair was "without a stain on his character" but Dominic Grieve branded the office operation as "scandalous". He told Today programme: "I know David very well and believe him to be a man of real integrity and real ability. I am so sad for him about what happened."

He offered a large sum to ensure his return, but there were definite promises about future jobs, referring to the elite body guard of Roman emperors. But senior Labour backbencher Martin O'Neill, who chairs the Commons trade committee, believes he would have another side to the prime minister's offer if Mr Blunkett could serve as a cabinet-level figure. However, Ian Gibson, chairing the science and technology committee, suggested a "question mark" regarding his potential service.
